explanation: The report is correct. The call strncpy(_metal.page_sizes[index].path, path, PATH_MAX) can read up to PATH_MAX bytes from the source pointer without any check that the source object is NUL-terminated within PATH_MAX or that the source object has at least PATH_MAX bytes. metal_add_page_size only checks for path != NULL (and shift > 0) — there is no proof in the presented code that every caller supplies a char object that is NUL-terminated within PATH_MAX or that points to a buffer of size >= PATH_MAX. Under those conditions strncpy may read beyond the bounds of the object referenced by path (and, separately, may leave the destination without a terminating NUL if the source length >= PATH_MAX). This violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. A safe fix is to ensure the source is a proper NUL-terminated string (or has known length >= PATH_MAX) before calling strncpy, or to use a bounded copy pattern that checks strnlen(path, PATH_MAX) and copies that many bytes and writes a terminating NUL (or use snprintf/explicit memcpy+terminate).
